Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIPELINE Network project will significantly enhance physics education by developing and evaluating methods to incorporate workforce-relevant skills and activities in the student experience. The majority of physics graduates at all degree levels will become scientists and innovators working in the private sector, yet very little of the knowledge they gain while earning their degree specifically prepares them for these roles (for example, few physics programs emphasize real-world applications of scientific concepts, communication skills, or basic business concepts, all of which are important to successful private sector careers). Adding workforce-relevant learning to the discipline will attract a larger and more diverse student body to major in physics, and by extension improve the quality of the future STEM workforce. The PIPELINE project will bring together efforts of six institutions to create and document new approaches to teaching innovation and entrepreneurship in physics which can be shared with the broader community. The project will also advance our understanding of how these practices affect student and faculty attitudes towards innovation and entrepreneurship in physics.

The goals of the PIPELINE network are to build students' workforce confidence, improve physics faculty attitudes toward private sector careers, foster better integration of academic and industrial sectors, promote innovation in the physics discipline, and build a framework for wider adoption of physics innovation and entrepreneurship practices. The project will accomplish these by implementing physics innovation and entrepreneurship (PIE) approaches at member institutions during each year of the project, revising approaches between iterations, and finally documenting and disseminating curriculum. Most importantly, PIPELINE will develop surveys and interview protocols which will investigate the link between PIE experiences and student and faculty attitudes about innovation and entrepreneurship, and which can be used by other departments for gauging, monitoring, and improving institutional change around PIE. These research findings and tools will provide insights and utility that go beyond the immediate partner institutions, and live on beyond the duration of the project. PIPELINE will generate a core network of experienced PIE practitioners, a readily accessible body of tested PIE curricula deliberately varied in scope to fit unique needs and challenges of future adopters, and robust insight into the obstacles to PIE implementation and how future adopters might address them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PIPELINE project sought to develop and integrate activities, courses, and experiences at the undergraduate level that would better prepare physics graduates for a wide variety of future career pathways (many of which lay outside of academia), and also inspire and empower physics students to make a difference in the world through developing innovative solutions to human challenges. This approach is called physics innovation and entrepreneurship (PIE) education. The project also sought to better understand the reasons that students chose to major in/identify with physics, as well as the barriers to widespread adoption of the approaches developed in the project by physics faculty. 

Key outcomes of the project include:

  • Development of new curricular approaches to teaching PIE. The seven PIPELINE institutions each developed a wide variety of activities or modules that can be used in introductory, intermediate, and advanced physics courses.

  • Cross-testing of these curricular approaches among the seven PIPELINE institutions. PIPELINE faculty tried approaches developed at different institutions and were able to provide feedback on how they might be improved for use in institutions with varying resource landscapes.

  • Establishment of a community of practice through numerous workshops, sessions, and discussions at conferences such as the American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT) and American Physical Society (APS) Meetings. A new working group (called the 'Physics for Tomorrow' group) was also formed comprised of PIPELINE team members and members of other groups focused on integrating scientific and computational skills into the undergraduate physics curriculum (such as the Partnership for Integration of Computation into Undergraduate Physics (PICUP) and the Advanced Laboratory Physics Association (ALPhA)). This group seeks to build off existing successes in all of our programs to achieve more widespread communty support for workforce relevant skill integration in undergrauduate physics. An initial webinar for the PICUP community attracted about 40 faculty participants and fostered a lively discussion.

  • The creation of a PIE newsletter which had nearly 300 physics faculty subscribers. The monthly publication detailed developments within the PIPELINE project, as well as tools and resources that subscribers could use to teach to bring innovation and entrepreneurship ideas into their own teaching, e.g. societies and organizations that promote entrepreneurship education, such as VentureWell.

  • The creation and distribution of a report, Educating Physicists for Impactful Careers (EPIC), detailing curricular approaches developed during the project, providing arguments for why PIE education is important, and recommendations for funding agencies, university administrations, and professional societies on how to better support physics faculty interested in teaching PIE. This report was distributed to over 1,500 department chairs and physics faculty in June 2021.

  • The creation of a website that also presents the report content and the curricular materials developed under the project, in a fully searchable format. The creation of the website facilitates wider sharing and implementation of the approaches. There have been 3,200 visits to the site since its launch in early June 2021.

  • Insights into what motivates physics students to choose physics as a major specifically through the lens of career development, including the connection between physics and societal impact. Insights were also gained into the major obstacles for widespread adoption of PIE practices by physics faculty. The student survey included approximately 200 participants from physics departments across the country.

    Insights into student attitudes towards physics (in particular its connection with social impact among women students) help support arguments for further PIE adoption as a way to foster diversity in physics, since PIE encourages students to use their scientific and technical skills to create innovative solutions to problems facing the world. Insights into faculty barriers will help inform future efforts to design better PIE curricula and create buy-in of future adopters.
